content.description:
Climb the first pitch of the aid route Bladerunner to the two bolt anchor. Easier start leads to a technical corner followed by some fun and burly overhanging crack.



The line starts in the centre of Kashmir wall and follows the obvious slanting crack.

Single rack. Nuts to BD # 3.

A varied line starting on a steep slanting finger crack. Climb in to a difficult slabby corner on micro cams/RP's. Continue to an overhanging layback corner with pumpy and bouldery climbing to the chains.



Starts 2m left of Bladerunner. Kashmir Wall. 

Full double rack RP's to BD #3's.

An amazing climb seldom visited and unlike anything in Squamish. Steep, powerful, exposed and full value! 
  
 Climb P1 of Tintin in Tibet. Also climb the first ~ six metres of P2 of Tintin in Tibet, but where that route veers right up the corner, this route stays on the slanted slab and continues left. Follow this awkward feature for a few more metres until you reach an rest and obvious point when the moderate climbing ends. At this point, you climb a steep and exposed left-slanting crack under a roof with amazing finger locks, but horrible feet. The crux is only a few metres long, but it packs a punch. Stopping to place gear whilst campusing on finger locks my be the true crux. Once you reach a rest, regain some energy and fire straight up and along a left-facing corner to the top. This top section is moderate by comparison, but milk the rests to make sure you get the send!

Gear to 2". Doubles in the finger size (and smaller) for the crux.

A quality sport route that serves as a good warmup for the other routes on the wall. Located towards the left of the wall, scramble up onto an obvious ledge of stacked boulders and spot the bolts.  
  
 Easier climbing at the start leads through to some tenuous moves higher up.

About 10 QD's + anchor material. Anchor is two large bolts.

This route combines Kashmir and the aid route Bladerunner for some exciting free climbing in very overhanging terrain. No hardware was added to the aid pitches.

P1. First pitch of Kashmir. 5.11c. Bolts.

P2. Traverse across a face from the Kashmir anchors to join the third pitch of the aid route Bladerunner. 5.13b. Mixed. Wild! 

P3. Up a corner and in to some interesting moves pulling the lip before the chains. 5.12a. Gear.

P4.  Head left from the chains up some steep face moves followed by an exciting finish around the corner to the right. 5.12a. Gear



Start on Kashmir.

Gear to 3". 9? draws for first pitch.

climbs.name: Tintin in Tibet
climbs.fa: Will Stanhope, Jason Kruk and Gavin Tansley (2004)

content.description:
The start is located at the right of Kashmir Wall. The first pitch ascends the obvious left slanting corner and brings you to a bolted anchor. The start of P2 is the crux of the climb as you climb right off of the belay into a right-facing crack that is awkward - good locks but marginal feet. Once you're out of this crack and onto the slanted slab above, make a right turn (continuing left is Fandangler) up the corner and into a left-facing corner. Take this corner and top out to a two bolt anchor.

Pro to 2". Doubles in the finger sizes for P2. Some tiny pieces are helpful for P1.

Start with difficult and runout lay backing in to a mediocre rest. Place some cams and do the V12ish boulder problem to the ledge. Head right on the ledge past a bolt to an anchor. Twin ropes or long slings is not a bad idea due to the sharp arete.



Second pitch of Bladerunner in the middle of Kashmir Wall.

Tiny cams to fingers.

An impressive, steep and clean face. Quality rock. 
  
 Rarely visited, but often walked past for parties climbing The Ultimate Everything.  It is north facing and thus receives little sun - a great place for sky cragging in the warmer summer months.
